chunk text: covalently bonded hydrocarbon chain means a chain of carbon atoms, covalently bonded to each other and to one, or more, hydrogen atoms.
carboxyl group is acid radical -COOH. It releases H+ into aqueous solution to make the solution acidic.
saturated fatty acid means all the carbon–carbon bonds in the hydrocarbon chain are single bonds.
monounsaturated fatty acid means one of the carbon–carbon bonds is a double bond.
polyunsaturated fatty acid means more than one carbon–carbon bond is a double bond.
ester bond is the bond that forms between a carboxyl group and a hydroxyl group.
hydrophilic means water-loving.
hydrophobic means water-hating.
bilayer means two layers sandwiched together.
amino acids are the building blocks of proteins and have two functional groups – the amino group and the carboxyl group. This allows them to behave both as a base and as an acid.
peptide bond is the bond that links two amino acids.
polypeptide means a linear polymer consisting of amino acid residues bonded together in a chain forming a part or all of a protein molecule.
primary structure is the sequence formed by amino acids.
secondary structure is formed when a polypeptide chain folds itself into another structure.
α-helix is a coiled secondary structure of a polypeptide.
β-pleated sheet is a folded pleated sheet secondary structure of a polypeptide.
tertiary structure means folding of the secondary structure of a polypeptide by the formation of new bonds to hold it in place.
quaternary structure means structures formed when two or more polypeptide chains (folded into a tertiary structure) become associated in the final structure of the protein.
haemoglobin is the oxygen-carrying molecule in the blood.
collagen is fibrous protein found in many tissues in mammals.
DNA is a huge molecule made up of two strands of nucleotides wound into a double helix.
RNA is a molecule made up of one strand of nucleotides.
active site is the part of an enzyme molecule that binds with its substrate so that the enzyme can catalyse the chemical reaction.
substrate is a substance upon which an enzyme acts in a biochemical reaction.
enzyme–substrate complex is the intermediate formed, temporarily, when an enzyme binds to its substrate.
catalyst is a substance that speeds up a chemical reaction and remains unchanged at the end of the reaction.
Enzyme Commission is a body set up to produce a systematic way of naming enzymes.
topic: How do we name and classify enzymes?

chunk text: activation energy is the energy required to start off a chemical reaction.
topic: How do enzymes lower activation energy?

chunk text: lock-and-key model proposes that the shapes of the substrate molecules are complementary to that of the active site.
topic: How do enzymes lower activation energy?

chunk text: induced-fit model means the active site and substrate do not complement each other but the binding of substrate molecules produces a change in shape in the active site, allowing the substrate to fit the active site.
topic: How do enzymes lower activation energy?

chunk text: turnover rate is the number of molecules of reactants that form enzyme–substrate complexes with each molecule of an enzyme, per second.
topic: How do enzymes lower activation energy?

chunk text: denature means the alteration of the tertiary structure of a protein; in living cells this is reversible.
topic: 3.3 Factors affecting the functions of enzymes

chunk text: optimum temperature is the temperature at which an enzyme works most efficiently.
topic: 3.3 Factors affecting the functions of enzymes

chunk text: pH scale is the measure of the hydrogen ion concentration of a solution.
topic: 3.3 Factors affecting the functions of enzymes

chunk text: competitive inhibitor is a molecule that inhibits enzyme activity by competing with the substrate for the active site.
topic: How do other substances affect enzyme activity?

chunk text: non-competitive inhibitor is a molecule that alters the conformation of the active site by binding with the allosteric site of the enzyme; it prevents the substrate from binding and inhibits enzyme activity.
topic: How do other substances affect enzyme activity?

chunk text: end-product inhibition is when an end product inhibits the enzyme controlling the first stage of a reaction sequence.
topic: How do inhibitors control enzyme activity in living cells?

chunk text: activator is a substance that removes an inhibitor.
topic: How do inhibitors control enzyme activity in living cells?

chunk text: calibrating means to correlate the readings of an instrument with a standard.
principle of limiting factors means limitation by a factor that is present in a limiting quantity.
topic: What factors affect the rate of photosynthesis?

chunk text: photorespiration is a process involving the oxidation of carbon.
C4 photosynthesis means light-dependent reactions are the same as in C3 photosynthesis but the first compound formed in the light-independent reactions contains four carbons, not three.
